title: Schedule
text:
In general, there will be a mix of lecture material, interactive exercises, field excursions, and labs in the hours between breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Meals and the time before breakfast and after dinner will be reserved for socialization and free time for exploration and rest.
The local timezone is Mountain Daylight Time (UTC-6). Sunrise will be ~6:15am and sunset will be ~8:00pm.
Meals will be served in the billy barr Community Center (bbcc).

title: Schedule
text:
Prior to arrival: Prep work
We will have readings and prep-work for you to complete before the workshop begins. This will include things like installing and (re)familiarizing yourself with R.

title: IPMs: From field data collection to model construction and analysis
text:
Instructors

Will Petry, North Carolina State University
Amy Iler, Chicago Botanic Garden & Northwestern University

Paul CaraDonna, Chicago Botanic Garden & Northwestern University

title: Workshop materials
text:
ImportantUnder construction



Workshop materials will be posted closer to the start date.

title: FAQs
text:
TipWho is the intended audience for this workshop?





This workshop is designed for graduate students, postdocs, or faculty who are planning a demographic field study with the intention of building IPMs or those who already have census data and want to construct an IPM.









TipWhen will the workshop be held this year?





August 10–12, 2026 (Monday-Wednesday). Participants will arrive on the evening before (Sunday August 9) and depart the morning after (Thursday August 13).









TipWhere will the workshop be held?





The workshop will be hosted by Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory, a field station in the Rocky Mountains located in the town of Gothic near Crested Butte, Colorado.









TipHow many participants will there be?





We are anticipating 10-12 participants this year.









TipWill the workshop be run in future years?

title: FAQs
text:
Application






TipHow do I apply?



















TipWhen is the application deadline?





The deadline to receive full consideration is March XX, 2026. Late applications will only be considered if slots remain after the main round application review is completed.









TipWhen will I hear back about whether I have been invited to participate?





We aim to send emailed invitations by March XX, 2026.









TipIf I receive an invitation to participate, when do I need to decide whether to accept?

title: FAQs
text:
Cost, Housing & Dining






TipHow much does the workshop cost?















TipIs financial support available?















TipAre meals provided?





Yes, meals will be provided during the workshop. Please see Dining at RMBL.









TipWhat are the lodging accommodations?





The workshop fee includes on-site lodging in cabins at the Rocky Mountain Biological Lab. RMBL is built from the remains of a late 1800’s silver-mining town. Most participants will be staying in renovated but rustic cabins built in the 1960’s through 1990’s. See here for more information.

title: FAQs
text:
Travel & Packing






TipHow do I get to the workshop?

















TipCan I arrive a bit early or stay a bit later?





Most likely yes, but you will need to arrange a longer stay with RMBL staff.









TipI see an airport that looks closer than Denver. Can I book my flights through there?





Commercial flights are available into Gunnison, which is about 1 hour away from RMBL. The high mountain setting of this airport causes frequent flight cancellations in summer. This region experiences strong monsoonal thunderstorms. Modestly high temperatures also cause cancellations because the already low air density falls below the minimum needed for airplanes to takeoff and land. We consider flights through Gunnison to be unreliable if you need to travel on a specific date or want to avoid unexpected hotel stays en route.
Aspen is is not a viable alternative despite being very close to Gothic (<20 air miles / <30 km). The intervening terrain is very rugged Wilderness with high mountain passes with no direct road route. The shortest safe road route around these mountains takes 4-5 hours (>100 miles / >160 km, about 1/3 of that on dirt roads), and there is no mass transit option.

title: FAQs
text:
Diversity, Community, Health & Safety






TipHow high is the elevation, and how should I prepare?





Gothic, CO sits at 9,600 ft (2900 m) above sea level. Most people coming from low elevation experience mild symptoms from the reduced availability of oxygen. Best practices include hydrating well and getting enough sleep before and immediately after arriving to high elevation. Consider reducing or avoiding caffeine and alcohol. Individuals who anticipate a harder time adjusting to elevation may consider ascending slowly by arriving to Denver a few days early before ascending to Gothic.
The CDC offers more detailed guidance to high elevation travel.
